awd_titl_txt: EAGER-Black Women Work: Broadening Participation of Black Girls in Computer Science Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines Black women teachers' pre-service preparation in an effort to broaden participation of African American girls in computer science (CS) careers by developing their computational thinking (CT) skills. This study will examine how Black elementary school teachers learned to support their kindergarten through sixth grade African American female students to learn CT in efforts to inspire their futures in the CS workforce. The objective of this research is to understand how African American women teachers support Black students to enter computer science careers.  We will specifically examine: 1) teacher certification program components that build CT for elementary Black girls; 2) training in culturally responsive computing (CRC); 3) CRC training in ways that support African American girls; and 4) best practices for supporting Black teachers at institutions of higher education where teacher certification programs train predominately white future teachers. The overarching objective of this research study is to add to the literature by exploring how Black female teachers learn to inspire Black girls' participation in the CS workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Although research has been conducted on the influence of Black women teachers on Black students prior to desegregation, there is a dearth of literature on how Black women educators support Black students today, particularly in computing (Howell, Norris, & Williams, 2019; Johnson, 2015). To understand the impact of having Black women teachers on Black students, we conducted a mixed-methods study from September 2019 to June 2022 that examined how 10 Black women teachers recognized and engaged their students’ computational thinking skills. Findings from this work reveal that when the teachers incorporate Black Gaze Theory (Howell, Norris, Williams, 2019)  into their teaching and thereby see their students’ cultural assets, a phenomenon we term Reciprocal Recognition occurs. We define Reciprocal Recognition as a symbiotic relationship between Black women teachers and their Black students that allows them to see each other, to see past their historically marginalized positionalities, and appreciate the contributions each makes to teaching and learning. This research also illuminates Black women’s unique approach to effective teaching beyond the boundaries of what they learn in their teacher preparation programs (TPP) and the significance of what we term Femmenoir Pedagogies. It emphasizes the need to center Black women in TPP as experts using their socio-political location to harness their strengths and radically imagine ways to overcome racism and sexism in both their preparation and practice. Findings suggest Femmenoir Pedagogies arise from missing elements in TPP and shape the future success of Black women educators. This research draws on the life histories of the Black women teachers who revealed how they have overcome institutional barriers to success and how they see their work as a part of generational commitments to Black excellence and by extension more humanizing and culturally responsive educational spaces for all. 


Last Modified: 07/08/2022
Modified by: Aaminah Norris
